end.title: Top End Wedding dress
end.brief_description: Miranda Tapsell didn’t want Lauren in Top End Wedding to look like the stereotypical movie love interest – the star and co-writer of the First Nations rom-com wanted to celebrate Blak beauty. Costume designer Heather Wallace collaborated with Tiwi Designs on this stunning wedding dress, which marries silver-screen glamour with authentic Tiwi Island style. While the cut was influenced by golden era Hollywood gowns, the distinctive pattern and colours were inspired by the Tiwi Islands, where the celebratory wedding scene takes place. As Lauren beams and walks the aisle in an authentic headdress, it’s safe to say Tapsell achieved her dream.

start.title: Kiki and Kitty
start.brief_description: Kiki and Kitty follows the adventures of a young, black woman in a big, white world, where her vagina is a big, black woman AND her best friend.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

end.title: Basically Black
end.brief_description: Basically Black combined comedy, activism and performing arts while reflecting the political struggles and organising of 1960s and 70s Redfern. The first TV program written and performed by an all-Indigenous cast, this groundbreaking program tackled racism and white paternalism through humour.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

links.description: Kiki and Kitty creator Nakkiah Liu is one of the many writers and stars of ABC’s hit Black Comedy, the first Indigenous sketch show since Basically Black (1973). While Black Comedy enjoys mainstream success, Basically Black was censored for being too political.
